series.series.name: No-Fault Divorce Has Damaged the Family

abstract.p: Letter from J T Oldham says it would be bad idea to place limitations on no-fault divorce (S)

block.p: Americans seem to have a magical faith that change in law can engineer whatever new behavior is desired. The movement to limit divorce is a good example (Op-Ed, Jan. 13).
Americans seem to have a magical faith that change in law can engineer whatever new behavior is desired. The movement to limit divorce is a good example (Op-Ed, Jan. 13).

Even before no-fault divorce was accepted, most couples agreed to divorce. In those rare instances when one spouse did not want a divorce, the judgment was made that if one partner had made a decision no longer to try to make the marriage work, reconciliation was not possible. Barring divorce in such instances could lead to higher levels of spousal violence and informal desertion.

It would be a bad idea to place limitations on no-fault divorce. Before divorce is permitted, procedures should be created so that spouses do not divorce before they have made a rational decision to do so. Abolishing no-fault divorce would have many costs. Not least would be requiring people to stay married to people they no longer respect or care for.
The writer is a professor of law at the University of Houston.
No-Fault Divorce Has Damaged the Family
